subsc: General industry and trade sector,Power,Banking,Sub-national government administration,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project was rated highly
            satisfactory. The sustainability of Argentina's reform
            program was consolidated, partly, due to the success of
            public sector reforms among the project's participating
            provinces. Furthermore, the project became the link between
            municipal and national authorities, on policy issues central
            to the process of public sector reform. The key lessons
            suggest that structural adjustment loans, which are targeted
            at sub-national governments, may become key elements in
            successful reform programs, since they provide the forum for
            agreements on overall reform strategies. Nevertheless, this
            success was the result of various factors, of which, the
            strong political support was paramount. A sustained
            reduction of expenditures requires, and, depends on adequate
            incentives, both at the national and provincial levels,
            since financial support does not substitute adequate policy
            incentives. Windfall transfers and soft sources of deficit
            financing, undermine the potential for fiscal reform, thus
            early identification of post-stabilization measures should
            be in place during reform processes, as well as possible
            negotiations, to neutralize negative impacts, should soft
            financing occur. It is suggested that crises not only
            generate risks, but opportunities for large-scale provincial
            reforms. Reform leverage should be maximized through strict
            creditworthiness, and, focusing on few sub-national
            government's reforms.
